resist.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to stop yourself from having something that you like very much or doing something that you want to do
resist.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: They only wanted 3 dollars for it, so how could I resist?
It’s hard to resist an invitation like that.
it is hard/difficult/impossible to resist something
She resisted the temptation to laugh.
resist the temptation/urge to do something
She can never resist buying new shoes.
resist.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to try to prevent a change from happening, or prevent yourself from being forced to do something
resist.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The proposal was strongly resisted by the police.
For months the company has resisted changing its accounts system.
resist.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to use force to stop something from happening
resist.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He was charged with trying to resist arrest.
Demonstrators violently resisted attempts to remove them from the building.
resist.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to not be changed or harmed by something
resist.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: to stop yourself from having something that you like very much or doing something that you want to do
resist.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: resist the temptation to do something
He resisted the temptation to look back.
resist the urge/impulse to do something
Bob resisted the urge to touch her hand.
Bond could never resist the lure of a beautiful woman.
Mr Taylor is a man who cannot resist a challenge.
He was unable to resist the temptation to smoke.
The temptation to follow them was hard to resist.
The urge to give him a hug was almost impossible to resist.
resist.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: to try to prevent a change from happening, or prevent yourself from being forced to do something
resist.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: The Chancellor resisted pressure to increase taxes.
resist an attempt to do something
The rest of the board resisted his attempts to change the way things were done.
People resist change because they fear the unknown.
Barcelona strongly resisted moves by rival clubs to sign their star players.
The proposed change has been fiercely resisted by car companies.
They stubbornly resisted all attempts to modernize the factory.
He successfully resisted a challenge to his leadership.
resist.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to try to prevent something happening or changing
resist.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: It resisted a bid by the Denver company to acquire a 46% stake.
The board voted to file for bankruptcy, even though two directors resisted.
